data:
Generate a story and a one short sentence as a title in the journalism style. For the story you generate put the title at the first row. The story should involves the following entities and summary. Please make sure the story you generate is at least 500 words long.
Summary: A man who allegedly shot and wounded two Jewish men as they left synagogues in Los Angeles last month pleaded not guilty Thursday to federal hate crimes, authorities said. The shootings Feb. 15 and Feb. 16 brought fear into LA's Jewish community after officials said the victims were targeted because they wore clothing that identified their faith, including black coats and head coverings. He entered his not-guilty plea Thursday in federal court. Kate Corrigan, one of Tran's attorneys, said she expects to receive discovery-hearing evidence within the coming days as she prepares his defense. "We’ll be looking at the overall scenario in this case and addressing the charges," she said Thursday. Tran told law enforcement that he looked online for a "kosher market" and decided to shoot someone nearby, according at an affidavit filed by the FBI. Tran has "history of antisemitic and threatening conduct," an FBI affidavit said, citing a review of emails, text messages and unspecified reports. In 2022, he emailed former classmates using insulting language about Jewish people, and he threatened a Jewish former classmate, repeatedly sending them messages like "Someone is going to kill you, Jew" and "I want you dead, Jew," according to the affidavit.A man who allegedly shot and wounded two Jewish men as they left synagogues in Los Angeles last month has pleaded not guilty to federal hate crimes Suspect in shooting of 2 Jewish men in LA pleads not guiltyThe Associated PressLOS ANGELES LOS ANGELES (AP) — A man who allegedly shot and wounded two Jewish men as they left synagogues in Los Angeles last month pleaded not guilty Thursday to federal hate crimes, authorities said. Begin story:

Suspect in Shooting of 2 Jewish Men in LA Pleads Not Guilty

LOS ANGELES (AP) — Jaime Tran, the man accused of shooting and injuring two Jewish men outside of synagogues in Los Angeles last month, has pleaded not guilty to federal hate crimes.

The shootings, which occurred on February 15 and 16, sent waves of fear through LA's Jewish community as officials confirmed the victims were targeted because of their faith.

Tran entered his plea in federal court on Thursday, with his attorney, Kate Corrigan, saying they would be reviewing evidence obtained during the discovery hearing as they prepared his defense.

Meanwhile, the FBI filed an affidavit stating that Tran had a history of anti-Semitic and threatening behavior. The document cited a review of Tran's emails, text messages, and other reports that detailed his offensive language towards Jewish people and threats against a former Jewish classmate.

In 2022, he allegedly repeated messages such as "someone is going to kill you, Jew" and "I want you dead, Jew."

Tran allegedly told law enforcement officers that he searched online for a "kosher market" and decided to shoot someone nearby, according to the affidavit filed by the FBI.

The incident has raised concerns for the safety of the Jewish community in Los Angeles, with many urging law enforcement to take steps to prevent future acts of hate-motivated violence.

The Southern California branch of the organization SAY SAME, which advocates for the Jewish community and works to combat anti-Semitic activities, has condemned the attack and called for increased security measures at synagogues and other Jewish institutions.

Several media outlets, including FOX and the AP, have covered the story, with many highlighting the importance of standing together against hate and prejudice.

The city of Los Angeles has also spoken out against the attack, with Mayor Eric Garcetti offering his support and solidarity for the Jewish community.

"This type of hateful violence has no place in our city or any other," Garcetti said in a statement.

As the case against Tran moves forward, it remains to be seen what steps law enforcement will take to ensure the safety of Los Angeles' Jewish community and prevent future incidents of hate-motivated violence.
